data.title: Local roundup: Campbell on Team Ontario; Imperials in final; Ontario Games medallists
data.meta_description: Petrolia’s Hunter Campbell is on Team Ontario for the Royal Canadian Legion youth national track and field championships this weekend in Calgary.
data.text:
Petrolia’s Hunter Campbell is on Team Ontario for the Royal Canadian Legion youth national track and field championships this weekend in Calgary.

Article content

Campbell throws for Team Ontario

Article content

Petrolia’s Hunter Campbell is on Team Ontario for the Royal Canadian Legion youth national track and field championships this weekend in Calgary.

“Representing Ontario at nationals has been a dream that I have had since I was a little kid,” he wrote on social media. “That dream just became a reality. I am so grateful for this opportunity and I am amazed at how far that I have gotten in this sport already. … I am more than honoured to be able to represent this province.”

Campbell is seeded third in the under-18 boys’ discus slated for Friday. He’s also entered in the shot put and hammer.

He won silver in discus at the Ontario Legion championships in July.

Three Sarnia Athletics Southwest teammates are also at the youth nationals: Skarlit Worton in the U18 girls’ 100 and 200 metres, 100-metre hurdles and long jump; Lily Odolphy in the U18 girls’ 100 and 200 metres; and James Grant in the U18 boys’ 800 and 1,500 metres.

Imperials hosting Power 5 title game

The Sarnia Imperials will host the Sudbury Spartans in the inaugural Ontario Power 5 Football League championship game Saturday at 7 p.m. at Norm Perry Park.

General admission is $15. Ages five to 12 pay $5 and children under five are free.

The Imperials finished in a three-way tie for first place in the regular season at 4-2 and then beat the Tri-City Outlaws 37-14 in a semifinal.

Dante Lewis (offence) and Spencer Bollman (special teams) won the league’s player of the week awards.

The previously winless Spartans upset the Sault Steelers 8-6 in the other semifinal.

Lambton tour golfers win medals

Andrea Lai of the Lambton Junior Golf Tour won two silver medals while tour teammates Jadelina Tep-Chhun and Narisse Daye won one apiece at the Ontario Summer Games.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Lai was second in the girls’ individual standings at 4-over-par at the three-day tournament at FireRock Golf Club in Komoka. The Lambton tour was also in the girls’ team standings.

Tep-Chhun tied for ninth individually at 21 over and Daye was 12th at 23 over.

The Lambton tour was 10th in the boys’ team standings, led by Logan Woodiwiss at 19 over for a 27th-place tie. Gabriel Alexi Turno, Ryan Ladouceur, Lucas Rogers, Andrew Sudicky and Tayt Stonehouse were the other team members.

McCallum wins gold at Summer Games

Wyoming’s Ella McCallum scored for Team Nicole Gosling in a 5-0 win over Team Howe in the Ontario Summer Games girls’ hockey gold-medal game in London. She finished with two goals in five games.

Alvinston’s Mya Thorne had one goal in five games for fourth-place Team Hutchinson.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

In track and field, Laura Haggerty of Sarnia Athletics Southwest was sixth in the U16 girls’ long jump (4.68 metres) and triple jump (9.69 metres) and 15th in the 200 metres.

O’Rae hits first pro home run

Sarnia’s Dylan O’Rae hit his first home run as a professional Aug. 3 for the double-A Biloxi Shuckers in the Southern League.

O’Rae was 2-for-4 with three runs and three RBIs in the 13-4 win over the Rocket City Trash Pandas.

He’s hitting .199 with a .344 on-base percentage in 38 games with the Shuckers. He began the season with the high-A Wisconsin Timber Rattlers.

O’Rae, 20, is in his third pro season after being a Milwaukee Brewers third-round pick in the 2022 Major League Baseball draft. He’s played 168 games in the minors.

Sting alum Way joins Varsity Blues

Former Sarnia Sting captain Cooper Way is excited to start his university career with the Toronto Varsity Blues.

The 21-year-old centre from Waterloo graduated from the Ontario Hockey League after two consecutive 29-point seasons with the Sting.

“I chose to attend U of T because of the exciting challenges in both athletics and academics,” Way said in a statement. “Playing for a strong hockey team and earning an education from a significant school are both important to me, and University of Toronto was the school that checked both of these boxes. Everything, including the coaches, players, and community, all felt like a great fit for me to continue my hockey career. I am excited to live in Toronto, hang out with the guys, and chase a U Sports championship with the team.”

Article content

Nikandrov coaches Soo Greyhounds

Former Sting captain Daniel Nikandrov has been hired as a Soo Greyhounds assistant coach.

Nikandrov, 29, played one season with the Sarnia Legionnaires before spending most of his four-year OHL career with the Sting. He then played three seasons at York University.

He’s been a York assistant coach, Barrie Colts video coach, Don Mills Flyers head coach and St. Francis Xavier University assistant coach.

“Daniel’s coaching career has seen remarkable growth and it seems he is only beginning his journey,” Greyhounds general manager Kyle Raftis said in a statement. “We are fortunate to have the opportunity to welcome him to the Soo. We are confident that he will be a tremendous asset to our staff and a great resource for our players. His thorough attention to detail, along with his dedication to the development of players’ skills both on and off the ice, will greatly enhance our team and the program overall.”

Ace at Sarnia Golf

Tim Hummel hit a hole-in-one Wednesday at Sarnia Golf and Curling Club on the 92-yard 12th hole with a pitching wedge.

The witnesses were Steve Riches, Scott Hartley and Roy Baccari.
